questions.text: During your labor room postings, a vaginal examination of a primigravida female revealed the anterior cervix having soft consistency and showing 3 cm dilatation and a cervical length of 3 cm. You would assign a Bishop score of 1 to which of these cervical parameters in this patient?
questions.solution:
Among the given parameters, cervical length of 3 cm is given a score of 1 whereas a score of 2 is given for all the other parameters.

The Bishop score is a scoring system used to assess labor induction outcomes. It is based on the station of the head, dilation, effacement (or length), position, and consistency of the cervix noted by doing a vaginal examination.

Note: In the modified Bishop score (1991), the effacement is replaced by the cervical length in cm.

From the data given in the question:

  • Length of the cervix is 3 cm, hence score = 1
  • Position of the cervix is Anterior, hence score = 2
  • Cervical dilatation is 3 cm, hence score = 2
  • Consistency of cervix is soft, hence score = 2

Related Pearl: Bishop’s Score (Modified)

Score 0 1 2 3
Dilatation (cm) Closed 1-2 3-4 5+
Cervical length (cm) >4 2-4 1-2 <1
Consistency Firm Medium Soft -
Position Posterior Midline Anterior -
Head-Station -3 -2 -1, 0 +1, +2

Total score = 13

Favourable= 6-13

Unfavourable= 0-5

Note: 

  • According to NICE guidelines, a score of 6-13 is favorable for induction of labour.
  • According to Williams Obstetrics (26th edition), a score of 9 or more indicates a high likelihood of successful induction.

questions.text: A 40-year-old G2P1  woman with 18 weeks of amenorrhea comes to the casualty with intense abdominal pain with examination revealing cervical dilation, effacement, and bulging of membranes. In the transvaginal ultrasound, the cervical length is 15mm. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of mid-trimester cervical dilatation and a short cervix suggests cervical incompetence and the presence of cervical effacement, bulging of membranes or dilation or either of them necessitates an emergency cerclage.

Cervical incompetence or insufficiency is a functional or anatomical impairment in the retentive power of the cervix (or internal os). It is characterized by repeated, mid-trimester painless cervical dilatation. It leads to the escape of amniotic fluid followed by painless expulsion of the products of conception.

Cerclage is the procedure done to strengthen the cervix in patients with cervical incompetence. Contraindications of cervical cerclage include:

  • Ruptured membranes
  • Intrauterine infection
  • Uterine contractions
  • Vaginal bleeding
  • Cervical dilatation >4 cm
  • Fetal death or defect

Cervical incompetence is associated with various risk factors such as prior preterm birth, congenital uterine anomalies, iatrogenic (dilatation and curettage, induced abortion by dilatation and evacuation, vaginal operative delivery through an undilated cervix, amputation of the cervix, etc), and multiple gestations.

In the interconceptional period, diagnosis is made with the passage of number 6-8 Hegar's dilator beyond the internal os without resistance or pain. Investigations for cervical incompetence during pregnancy include:

  • Per speculum examination - shows cervical dilatation with herniation of membranes
  • Transvaginal ultrasound - funneling of internal os >1 cm and cervical length <25 mm
Prophylactic cervical cerclage is done between 12-14 weeks of gestation. Rescue or emergency cerclage is done when there is bulging or prolapse of membranes through a dilated cervix.
 
Shirodkar and McDonald's methods of cervical cerclage are the commonly performed cerclage procedures during pregnancy. In McDonald's method, a non-absorbable (mersilene) suture material is placed as a purse-string suture at the level of the internal os, whereas in the Shirodkar method, non-absorbable (mersilene) tape is used. Removal of stitches should be done at the 37th week of gestation. It can be removed earlier in case of preterm labour or if signs of abortion are seen. Laparoscopic abdominal cerclage is used for non-pregnant patients.
 
Other options:
 
Option B: A Mc Donalds' cerclage is transvaginally performed and is one of the most commonly used (simpler to perform) cerclage. It is indicated when the patient has a history of >/=3 abortions owing to cervical insufficiency or a history of >/=2 or more abortions owing to cervical insufficiency along with evidence of a short cervix. 
 
Option C: Vaginal progesterone is indicated in patients with only a short cervix.
 
Option D: This is a very radical procedure, hence is not performed. Reducing the membranes can be used as a part of performing an emergency cerclage but should not be followed with colpocleisis which is usually performed in old patients with pelvic organ prolapse as a last resort and who are no longer sexually active.

questions.text: In which of the following stages of puberty does estrogen not have a major role?
questions.solution:
Pubarche, or the development of pubic hair, is not mediated by estrogen.

In both sexes, adrenal androgen secretion is responsible for adrenarche—the development of axillary and pubic hair. The eventual phenotypical result of adrenarche is pubarche, increased oiliness of hair and skin, and acne.

Puberty refers to the period of transition from childhood to adult sexual maturation. On average, puberty typically begins between the ages of 8 and 13 years in females and 9 and 14 years in males. 

The following changes occur in puberty:

  • Thelarche refers to breast development, which signifies the start of puberty in girls. It is due to the action of estrogen and progesterone.
  • Pubarche occurs after thelarche, and refers to the appearance of pubic hair. Adrenarche refers to the increased secretion of adrenal androgens which leads to pubarche.
  • Growth spurt occurs due to a rise in sex steroids, which leads to an increase in growth hormone levels and IGF-1.
  • Menarche refers to the beginning of menstruation due to an increase in follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH).

questions.text: A 37 week G2P1L1 lady comes with reduced fetal movements. Her non-stress test shows a non-reactive trace. The fetus has 3 discrete gross body movements and opens and closes the palm 2 times. There are two amniotic fluid pockets measuring 2 cm in two perpendicular planes. The sonologist counts 2 fetal breathing episodes lasting 30 secs and 45 secs. What is the Manning score in this case?
questions.solution:
The Manning Score/Biophysical Score is 8 in this case, adding the scores on the following parameters:

  • The trace is nonreactive (NST) - Score of 0
  • ≥3 discrete body/limb movements (gross body movements) - Score of 2
  • Opens and closes the palm 2 times (fetal muscle tone) - Score of 2
  • 2 pockets measuring 2 cm in two perpendicular planes (amniotic fluid) - Score of 2
  • 2 fetal breathing episodes lasting 30 secs and 45 secs (fetal breathing movements) - Score of 2

Biophysical score/ Manning score:

  • It consists of 5 variables.
  • Parameters are observed for a period of 30 mins.
  • Each parameter has a maximum score of 2 and a minimum score of 0. Therefore, the total maximum score will be 10.
Parameter Normal criteria of score 2
Non-stress test Reactive pattern
Fetal breathing movements ≥1 episode lasting  > 30 second
Gross body movements ≥3 discrete body/limb movements
Fetal muscle tone ≥1 episode of active extension (limb or trunk) with the return of flexion; opening and closing of the hand, considered normal
Amniotic fluid ≥1 pocket measuring 2 cm in two perpendicular planes (2 × 2 cm pocket)

 

Score Interpretation
8- 10 Normal
6-7 Equivocal
≤5 Abnormal-  suspect asphyxia

 

Biophysical Score  Interpretation  Management 
8-10 Normal;
less risk of fetal asphyxia		 Repeat testing weekly or more 
6 Suspect chronic asphyxia  >36weeks- deliver 
Can repeat test after 4-6 hours to look for improvement 
4 Suspect chronic asphyxia 

>36 weeks- deliver 
<32 weeks- repeat testing in 4-6 hours for 120mins 
If score still </=4, deliver 
2 Strongly suspect asphyxia  >36 weeks- deliver 
<32 weeks- repeat testing in 4-6 hours for 120mins 
If score still </=4, deliver

 

Modified Biophysical Score: Only 2 parameters are included in the biophysical score, which are NST and AFI.

questions.text:
Which of the following factors are responsible for fetal bradycardia?
  1. Maternal hypoglycemia
  2. Prolonged hypoxia
  3. Head compression
  4. Anemia
  5. Epidural analgesia
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1, 2, 3 and 5.

Causes of fetal bradycardia (FHR<110bpm):

  • Prolonged fetal hypoxia, acidosis
  • Fetal sepsis, anomalies
  • Maternal hypoglycemia and hypothermia
  • Fetal heart conduction block (SLE)
  • Epidural analgesia
  • Intake of drugs like pethidine, antihypertensives (methyl dopa, propranolol), and magnesium sulphate by the mother.

Causes of fetal tachycardia (FHR>160bpm):

  • Drugs to mother - tocolytics such as isoxsuprine, and ritodrine, and vagolytics like atropine.
  • Maternal hyperthyroidism and metabolic acidemia
  • Infection
  • Anemia
  • Mild fetal hypoxia

Mild hypoxia causes fetal tachycardia whereas prolonged hypoxia in the fetus leads to an increase in blood lactate level and severe metabolic acidosis causing a drop in heart rate.

Low baseline heart rate is also seen in head compression from occiput posterior or transverse positions during second-stage labor.

questions.text: During the normal delivery of a primigravida with polyhydramnios, an intern prematurely attempts to remove the placenta, leading to profuse bleeding. Examination reveals that the placenta is still partly attached and that the uterus is partly outside the introitus. The patient is in hemorrhagic shock, so initial resuscitative measures are taken. What is the appropriate management in this situation among the following options?

choices.text: Manual repositioning of the uterus alone
Attempt repositioning and administer a trial of tocolytics

questions.solution:
The patient is diagnosed with uterine inversion with the placenta still attached and the appropriate management in this condition is to attempt repositioning of the uterus and administer a trial of tocolytics.

The given clinical scenario of hemorrhagic shock after attempts of forceful removal of the placenta is suggestive of uterine inversion. It is a hemorrhagic complication encountered in the puerperium. Polyhydramnios in this patient contribute to uterine atony.

Risk factors for uterine inversion include:

  • Fundal attachment of the placenta
  • Uterine atony
  • Attempts at cord traction before placental delivery
  • Adherent placenta

There are 3 degrees of uterine inversion:

  • First-degree - the fundus of the uterus inverts into the uterine cavity
  • Second-degree - the uterine fundus protrudes through the cervix and lies in the vagina
  • Third-degree -  the whole of the uterus is inverted and protrudes through the introitus

Since uterine inversion presents with profuse bleeding and a severe degree of shock, it requires prompt diagnosis and management. Management includes:

  • Call for help and arrange blood products.
  • Evaluate for general anaesthesia.
  • Administer rapid crystalloid infusion through a large-bore IV cannula.
  • If the placenta has separated and the uterus recently inverted - The uterus is replaced by manually pushing up on the fundus with the palm and fingers in the direction of the long axis of the vagina.
  • If the placenta is still attached-
    • Attempt repositioning and administering a trial of tocolytics (Option C). This trial of tocolytics helps in uterine relaxation and also repositioning of the uterus. Terbutaline, magnesium sulfate, or nitroglycerin may be used. Once the uterus is repositioned, the placenta is removed manually. 
    • In case the attempt to reposition fails, the placenta is peeled off and once again uterine repositioning is attempted. Once the anatomy is restored, tocolytics are withheld and ureterotonic agents are started. Manual pressure (Bimanual compression) is applied. (Option B)
  • A Bakri balloon is used to maintain the repositioned uterus. (Option D)
  • If repositioning fails, Surgical intervention(laparotomy) is indicated.

questions.text:
During a biochemical screening, an obstetrician identifies that a woman is carrying a fetus with trisomy 18. Which of the following markers would likely be low in this screening test?

1. Maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein
2. Beta human chorionic gonadotropin
3. Unconjugated estriol
4. Pregnancy-associated plasma protein A
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1, 2, 3, and 4. All of the above-given findings are decreased in trisomy 18 (Edward's syndrome). Maternal serum AFP, beta hCG, unconjugated estriol, and pregnancy-associated plasma protein A levels are reduced.

Combined first-trimester screening tests: It is performed between 11 and 14 weeks gestation. It comprises of:

  • Human chorionic gonad­otropin (hCG)
  • Pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A)
  • Sonographic measurement of the nuchal translucency (NT)

The abnormalities seen on the triple screen are tabulated below:

 Parameter Trisomy 21 Trisomy 18 Neural tube defect or abdominal wall defect
MSAFP Low Low High
β hCG High Low Normal
Unconjugated estriol Low Low Normal

Quadruple testing is done in the second trimester between 15-21 weeks of gestation. It comprises:

  • Maternal serum AFP
  • Human chorionic gonadotropin
  • Unconjugated estriol
  • Inhibin A

Trisomy 18 or Edwards’ syndrome is a condition characterised by intellectual disability, micrognathia, low-set ears, rocker-bottom feet, and congenital heart diseases. The most characteristic finding is a clenched fist with overlapping fingers i.e. the index finger overlies the third and fourth fingers, while the fifth finger overlaps the fourth. This syndrome is also associated with polyhydramnios and a single umbilical artery.

questions.text: A young woman, who was diagnosed with threatened abortion was referred to you from the peripheral hospital for an ultrasonography. Examination of this patient would reveal:

choices.text: Closed cervical os with absent fetal cardiac activity on USG
Closed cervical os with fetal cardiac activity on USG
Dilated cervical os with absent fetal cardiac activity on USG
Dilated cervical os with fetal cardiac activity on USG

questions.solution:
Examination of a patient diagnosed with threatened abortion would reveal closed cervical os with fetal cardiac activity on USG.

In threatened miscarriage, the process of miscarriage has started but has not progressed to a state from which recovery is impossible. 

Features:

  • Bleeding which is usually slight and may be brownish or bright red in color
  • Usually painless but pain appears following hemorrhage
  • Closed external os
  • Uterine size corresponds to the period of amenorrhea
  • Uterus and cervix feel soft
  • Transvaginal Ultrasonography shows well-formed gestation ring indicating healthy fetus with fetal cardiac activity.

Abortion is the expulsion or extraction from the mother of an embryo or fetus weighing 500 g or less when it is not capable of independent survival.

Classification of abortion:

Other options:

Option A: In missed abortion, the fetus is dead and is retained inside the uterus for a variable period. Here closed cervical os with absent fetal cardiac activity on USG can be seen.

Option C: In incomplete abortion, entire products of conception are not expelled, instead, a part of it is left inside the uterine cavity. Here dilated cervical os with absent fetal cardiac activity on USG can be seen.

Option D: In inevitable abortion, the changes have progressed to a state from where continuation of pregnancy is impossible. Here dilated cervical os with fetal cardiac activity on USG can be seen.

Related Pearl: Clinical classification of Spontaneous Abortion

questions.text: A 28-year-old female patient in her 16th week of gestation came for prenatal karyotyping since her first child is suffering from Down's syndrome. Which among the following statements is false regarding the procedure shown in the image?

choices.text: Limb reduction defect is a known complication

questions.solution:
The procedure shown in the image is amniocentesis. Limb reduction defect is not a known complication of amniocentesis, it is a complication of chorionic villous sampling. 

Amniocentesis is the most common prenatal diagnostic procedure. It is performed using an aseptic technique, under direct sonographic guidance, using a 20–22 gauge spinal needle. The needle is directed perpendicularly into a clear pocket of amniotic fluid while avoiding the fetus and umbilical cord. Sonography is used to observe the uterine puncture site for bleeding and fetal cardiac motion is documented at the end of the procedure. Approximately 20 to 30 mL of fluid is collected for fetal karyotyping or chromosomal microarray analysis. 

Study material

Amniotic fluid with amniocytes

Time

15-20 weeks

Early amniocentesis

11-14 weeks (associated with increased fetal loss, foot deformities)

Indications

Congenital infections

Fetal genetic disorders

Alloimmunization

Assessment of lung maturity
Complications

Fetal loss

Amniotic fluid leakage

Transvaginal spotting

 

Below is an image showing the procedure of amniocentesis vs chorionic villus sampling.

Related Pearl: Prenatal screening for Down’s syndrome

  • USG findings
    • Intrauterine growth retardation (so decreased blood flow)
    • Choroid plexus cysts
    • Increased nuchal translucency >3 mm
    • Hypoplastic nasal bone
    • Congenital heart defects
    • Increased intestinal echogenicity
    • Duodenal atresia
  • Maternal serum markers
    • Decreased: Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), unconjugated estriol, pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A)
    • Increased: Human chorionic gonadotrophin (HCG), inhibin, neutrophil alkaline phosphatase
  • Amniocentesis: 14th-18th week of pregnancy
  • Chorionic villus sampling
    • 10th to 12th week of pregnancy: Gives the diagnosis in the first trimester

questions.text: The obstetric grip performed in the picture is used to detect ______.

choices.text: The fetal pole occupying the fundus

questions.solution:
The obstetric grip shown in the picture is the Pelvic grip (Leopold's fourth grip) and it is used to detect the degree of descent.

Obstetric grips (Leopold maneuvers):

Leopold Grip Importance
First Fundal To know which fetal pole occupies the uterine fundus.
Second Lateral/Umbilical To know the fetal back and extremities 
Third Pawlick 

To know presenting fetal part in respect to the true pelvis
Fourth  Pelvic

To determine the degree of descent.

If the head has already descended into the pelvis, the anterior shoulder or the space created by neck may be differentiated readily from the head

The four grips of Leopold:

questions.text: You are performing intrauterine insemination during the ovulatory period in a patient with infertility. When will you expect implantation to occur if the insemination is successful?
questions.solution:
The implantation of the blastocyst in the uterine cavity occurs 6–7 days after fertilization.

Implantation involves: 

  •  Apposition: Blastocyst starts to establish contact with the uterine wall
  •  Adhesion: Increase in the physical interaction between the blastocyst and the uterine epithelium
  •  Invasion: Syncytiotrophoblasts and cytotrophoblasts penetrate and invade the endometrium

Prior to implantation, the endometrium is primed with estrogen and progesterone from the corpus luteum. This uterine receptivity is maximal from the 20th to 24th days of the endometrial cycle. Failure of embryo transfer during this time period may result in repeated implantation failure in IVF patients. 

Adherence of the blastocyst to the uterine cavity is a result of interaction between the cell-surface receptors at the implantation site and the blastocyst receptors. 

Related Pearl: Timeline of Various Events Occurring during the Pre-embryonic Phase Development (1st two weeks)

5–8 cell stage

3–4 days

4–5 days

5–6 days

Zona pellucida disappears

6–7 days

9 days

12 days

Formation of extraembryonic mesoderm

questions.text:
The correct heirarchy of steps to be followed during the management of a case of atonic postpartum hemorrhage not responding to uterine massage is:

1. Bimanual compression of the uterus
2. Ligation of uterine artery
3. Manual exploration of the uterus for removing any retained placental fragments
4. B-lynch compression
5. Tamponade using hydrostatic balloon catheter
questions.solution:
Option C represents the correct sequence of steps that are used to control atonic postpartum haemorrhage not responding to the uterine massage.

The following are the steps used in controlling postpartum hemorrhage:

  • Feel the uterus to know the cause of the haemorrhage. If the uterus feels flabby, bleeding is likely to be due to atonicity. If it is firm and contracted, it is likely to be traumatic in origin.
  • In case of an atonic uterus, massage the uterus and start the patient on oxytocin drips or methergine. 
  • If the uterus remains atonic, manual exploration of the uterus is done for removing any retained placental fragments. Blood transfusion is started and oxytocin drips are continued. Other uterotonic agents can also be given.
  • Uterine massage and bimanual compression
  • Uterine tamponade using a hydrostatic balloon catheter (balloon tamponade)
  • Surgical methods to control PPH are outlined as stepwise uterine devascularization procedures:
    • Compression sutures: B-Lynch suture
    • Ligation of uterine arteries
    • Ligation of ovarian and uterine anastomosis
    • Ligation of internal iliac artery
    • Angiographic embolization of the bleeding vessel
  •   Hysterectomy 
Uterotonic drugs Dose for treatment of PPH Dose for prevention of PPH
Oxytocin 10 IU - IM/IV 10 IU - IM/IV
Carbetocin 250 μg - IM 100 μg - IM/IV
Misoprostol 600-1000 μg - oral/rectal/ sublingual 400 μg or 600 μg, per-oral
Ergometrine
/methylergometrine		 200 μg - IM 200 μg - IM/IV

To effectively prevent PPH, the WHO recommends the use of only one of the uterotonic agents mentioned above. Of these, oxytocin is used as the first-line agent in preventing postpartum hemorrhage. When oxytocin is not available, the other drugs mentioned above can be used based on the clinical condition and availability of the drug.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the musculature of the uterus?

choices.text: The intermediate layer is the thickest layer
The circular layer is called the living ligature
Longitudinal fibers are continuous with the round ligaments

questions.solution:
The intermediate layer is called the living ligature.

The myometrium of the uterus has 3 layers of fibers, outer longitudinal, inner circular, and intermediate layer (from outside to inside). 

The outer longitudinal layer arches over the fundus like a hood and is continuous with the round ligaments.

The inner circular layer is thin and has a sphincter-like arrangement at the tubal orifices and internal os.

The intermediate layer is the thickest and strongest layer. The fibers are arranged in a criss-cross manner through which the blood vessels pass. The fibers give the figure of 8 forms when two double-curve muscle fibers appose. 

The intermediate layer is called the living ligature because it occludes the blood vessels running through the fibres during contraction helping in the prevention of blood loss and postpartum hemorrhage.

questions.text: A baby is being delivered in vertex presentation with the head in the attitude of marked deflexion. What will be the engaging diameter of the head of the baby in this case?
questions.solution:
Occipitofrontal diameter is seen in vertex presentation with a marked deflexion attitude of the head.

Diameters of the fetal skull:

Diameters Measurement Attitude of the head Presentation
Suboccipitobregmatic 9.5 cm Complete flexion Vertex
Suboccipito-frontal 10 cm Incomplete flexion Vertex
Occipitofrontal 11.5 cm Marked deflexion Vertex
Mento-vertical 14 cm Partial extension Brow
Submentovertical 11.5 cm Incomplete extension Face
Submentobregmatic 9.5 cm Complete extension Face

questions.text: A cervical mucus study was done on a 23-year-old woman. The microscopic picture appears as given below. Which of the following is not true?

choices.text: It is due to the presence of sodium chloride in the mucus
Progesterone causes loss of this pattern
Persistence of this pattern indicates ovulation
This pattern is a part of the Insler scoring system

questions.solution:
The image shows a specimen of dried cervical mucus showing a charectaristic pattern of fern formation termed ferning. It occurs under the influence of estrogen. Ferning disappears after ovulation

Fern test:

A drop of cervical mucus is spread and dried on a glass slide and observed under the low-power microscope. 

In the preovulatory (oestrogenic) phase, a characteristic pattern of fern formation is observed due to the presence of sodium chloride in the mucus secreted under the oestrogenic effect.

Following ovulation, ferning disappears due to progesterone activity. The disappearance of ferning is presumptive evidence of corpus luteum activity.

Insler devised a scoring system by just taking into account various properties of cervical mucus such as amount, ferning, viscosity, etc. as an inexpensive test of ovulation.

questions.text: In pregnant individuals, what is the most effective threshold for daily fetal movement counts (DFMC) to indicate potential fetal compromise?
questions.solution:
In pregnant individuals, the most effective threshold for daily fetal movement counts (DFMC) to indicate potential fetal compromise is less than 10 kicks in 12 hours (less than 3 in one hour).

Daily fetal movement count (DFMC) is a part of biophysical profile used for antepartum fetal surveillance. Three counts each of one hour duration (morning, noon and evening) is noted by the mother. The total counts multiplied by four gives daily fetal movement count (12 hours). If there is reduction in number of movement to less than 10 in 12 hours (less than 3 in each hour), it points towards fetal compromise.

The disappearance of the fetal heart rate (FHR) occurs within 24 hours after loss of fetal movements. In case where DFMC indicates fetal compromise, the mother is subjected to non-stress test (NST). 

Maternal hypoglycemia results in increased fetal movements. The fetal movements are perceived reduced by the mother with fetal sleep, fetal anomalies, anterior placenta, hydramnios, obesity, drugs, chronic smoking and hypoxia.

questions.text:
Match the given forceps with their respective indications.
1. Wrigley's forceps a. Delivery of after coming head in breech delivery
2. Kielland forceps b. Outlet forceps used to provide traction force
3. Piper forceps c. For transverse arrest in a patient with platypelloid pelvis
4. Barton forceps d. For rotational delivery in cases of unrotated vertex or face presentation
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1-b, 2-d, 3-a, 4-c.

The indications of the given forceps are:

1. Wrigley's forceps b. Outlet forceps used to provide traction force
2. Kielland forceps d. For rotational delivery in cases of unrotated vertex or face presentation
3. Piper forceps a. Delivery of after coming head in breech delivery
4. Barton forceps c. For transverse arrest in a patient with platypelloid pelvis

Related Pearl: Obstetrics forceps

Commonly used forceps: 

1) Simpson forceps

  • The most commonly used types of forceps in outlet delivery.
  • Has elongated cephalic curve.
  • These are used when there is substantial molding of the fetal head.

2) Elliot forceps

  • Has an adjustable pin for regulating the lateral pressure on the handles.
  • They are used most often when there is minimal molding.
  • More suitable for outlet delivery.

3) Kielland forceps

  • Has small pelvic curve and a sliding lock.
  • Suitable for head with little molding.
  • The most common forceps used for rotational delivery.
  • Helps correct asynclitism.

4) Piper forceps

  • Distinct perineal curve.
  • Allows for application to the after-coming head in breech delivery.

5) Tucker-McLane forceps

  • Suitable for fetal head with little molding.
  • Used in rotational delivery.

6) Barton forceps and traction handle

  • Used in rotational delivery.
  • Most importantly used for delivery of occipitotransverse positions in a platypelloid pelvis.
  • It is an obsolete procedure.

questions.text:
Which of the following hormones involved in water metabolism increases in pregnancy?
  1. Progesterone
  2. Aldosterone
  3. Angiotensin
  4. Deoxycorticosterone
  5. Arginine vasopressin (AVP)
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1, 2, 3, 4.

There is increase in estrogen, progesterone, renin, angiotensin, aldosterone system, and deoxycorticosterone. Plasma arginine vasopressin (AVP) levels, also known as antidiuretic hormone (ADH), remain unchanged. This is due to increased metabolic clearance of AVP by the enzyme vasopressinase from the placenta.

Around 6.5 litres of water is retained at term leading to a hypervolemic state during pregnancy. The sodium retention and volume overload state is due to changes in maternal osmoregulation, increased estrogen and progesterone, increase in renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) activity, increased deoxycorticosterone, control by AVP from posterior pituitary and atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP).

Polyuria in early pregnancy is due to the lowering of the osmotic threshold for thirst. The threshold for AVP secretion resets after 8 weeks and polyuria decreases.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presented with amenorrhea for the past 4 months. On performing USG, you notice the presence of twin gestation, with a characteristic appearance as shown in the image below. When will the division of the inner cell mass occur in this type of twin gestation?
questions.solution:
The given USG image depicts the T sign, which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation, for which division of the inner cell mass occurs at 4–8 days. 

Time of division Type of twin gestation
<3 days  Dichorionic diamniotic (DCDA) 
4–8 days Monochorionic diamniotic (MCDA)
>8 days Monochorionic monoamniotic (MCMA)
>13 days  Conjoint twins

 

"T sign" is the sonographic image seen in a monochorionic twin pregnancy. It refers to the lack of chorion extending between the layers of the intertwin membrane.

In monochorionic diamniotic gestation, the twins are separated only by the two amniotic membranes, with no intervening chorion. So, a thin T sign is formed at the point at which the amnions meet the placenta. It is best seen in the latter part of the first trimester or at the beginning of the second trimester. In monochorionic monoamniotic gestation, there is an absence of a dividing membrane.

In dichorionic gestation, the twins are separated by amniotic membranes and an intervening chorion. So, a thicker twin peak sign or lambda (λ) sign is formed at the point at which the amnions meet the placenta. It is best seen in the first trimester.

Related Pearl: Twinning

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: A mother of a newborn noticed vaginal discharge on her sixth-day postpartum. It was explained that it is normal and called lochia. Arrange the correct order of the appearance of lochia.
questions.solution:
The correct order of appearance of lochia is rubra-serosa-alba.

Lochia refers to the vaginal discharge resulting from the sloughing of decidual tissue in the early puerperal period. 

Name Colour Timings after delivery Contents
Lochia Rubra Red First few days  Blood, decidua, fetal membranes, Vernix, lanugo, meconium
Lochia Serosa Yellowish/pink After 3 to 4 days WBCs, cervical mucus, micro-organisms
Lochia Alba Pale White After 10th day Decidua, cells, WBC, mucin, cholesterin crystals and fat cells 

The average amount of discharge for the first week is 250 mL and may persist for about 3 weeks.

Malodorous lochia may signify underlying infection. Copious or absent lochia may also indicate infection or lochiometra. The persistence of lochia rubra beyond the normal limit may signify subinvolution or retained bits of the conceptus. Prolonged discharge of lochia alba for more than 3 weeks may signify local genital lesion.

questions.text: A primigravida at 34 weeks of gestation presents with bleeding per vaginum (PV). The bleeding was bright red, painless, spontaneous, and minimal. On examination, both the mother and fetus are stable.  According to Macafee and Johnson regimen, which of the following is not a part of expectant management in this patient?

choices.text: Gentle speculum examination 2-3 days after the bleeding has stopped

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a classical case of placenta previa. According to Macafee and Johnson expectant management, cervical cerclage is not advised to reduce bleeding or to prolong pregnancy as it is not helpful.

Placenta previa is characterized by abnormal implantation of the placenta over the lower uterine segment. It classically presents as painless, bright red vaginal bleeding that often stops spontaneously and then recurs. The bleeding most likely occurs in the late 3rd trimester, particularly in those with a placenta not covering the cervical os, bleeding is delayed until labor onset.

Management options can be divided into expectant management and active or definite management. 

Expectant management has been described by Macafee and Johnson.

Prerequisites: Blood should be available for transfusion if required, and facilities for cesarean section should be made available 24 hours a day.

The components of expectant treatment include: 

  • Bed rest with bathroom and toilet privilege
  • Investigations like hemoglobin estimation, blood grouping, urine for protein, etc
  • Periodic examination of vulval pads
  • Fetal surveillance with ultrasound at an interval of 2-3 weeks (Option A)
  • Supplementary hematinics should be provided
  • If the patient is anemic, then the loss of blood is treated with adequate cross-matched blood transfusion
  • 2-3 days after the bleeding stops, the patient is allowed out of bed and examined with a gentle speculum to rule out local causes of bleeding (Option D)
  • Tocolysis if bleeding is associated with uterine contractions (Option C)
  • Rh immunoglobulin to be given to Rh-negative mothers

Suitable cases for expectant management for placenta previa:

  • Mother in good health (Hb ≥10 g%; hematocrit ≥30%)
  • Duration of pregnancy <37 weeks
  • No active vaginal bleeding
  • Fetal well-being is assured (USG and cardiotocography)

Expectant management is continued only up to 37 weeks of gestation. 

Indications of definitive management (delivery) include :

  • Bleeding occurs at or after 37 weeks of pregnancy.
  • The patient is in labor.
  • The patient is in an exsanguinated state on admission.
  • Continuous bleeding and of a moderate degree.
  • Baby with nonreassuring cardiac status, dead, or known to be congenitally deformed. 

Patients with placenta previa confirmed on ultrasound are always scheduled for cesarean delivery, which is performed in patients who are near-term and are not currently bleeding. This is usually scheduled for 37-38 weeks of gestation. Vaginal delivery may be considered if the placental edge is 2-3cm away from the internal os as confirmed by ultrasound. 

The following image shows the different degrees of placenta previa.

questions.text: Oligohydramnios is defined as the single deepest vertical pocket of less than ____
questions.solution:
Oligohydramnios is defined as the single deepest vertical pocket of less than 2 cm.

Oligohydramnios is defined as:

  • Amniotic fluid volume<200ml
  • AFI<5cm
  • Single deepest vertical pocket <2cm

Causes include post-term pregnancy, renal agenesis, posterior urethral valve, persistent cloaca, sirenomelia (mermaid syndrome or single fused lower extremity that occupies the midline), amnion nodosum (failure of secretion by the cells of the amnion covering the placenta), etc.

Polyhydramnios is defined as:

  • Amniotic fluid volume>2L
  • AFI >24cm
  • Single deepest vertical pocket>8cm

Causes include diabetes, anencephaly, facial clefts, esophageal or duodenal atresia, Barter syndrome, ureteropelvic junction obstruction, aneuploidy, chorioangioma of the placenta, etc.

Related Pearl: Causes of oligohydramnios and polyhydramnios

  • Spontaneous rupture of membranes
  • Post-dated pregnancy
  • Preeclampsia

questions.text: A pregnant woman at her 30th week of pregnancy undergoes a pulmonary function test. Provided there is no respiratory abnormality, which of the following are likely to be seen physiologically?

choices.text: Increase in 1,2, and 7; no change in 3, 5 and 6
Increase in 1, 2 and 4; no change in 3, 5 and 7
Increase in 1 and 7; no change in 2 and 4
Increase in 3, 5 and 6; no change in 1 and 2

questions.solution:
Tidal volume and inspiratory capacity (1 and 7) increase physiologically during pregnancy, while inspiratory reserve volume and vital capacity (2 and 4) remain unchanged.

Changes in the respiratory system in pregnancy:

Increase

Decrease

Unaffected
  • Tidal volume
  • Inspiratory capacity
  • Minute O2 uptake
  • Minute ventilation
  • Functional residual capacity
  • Expiratory reserve volume
  • Residual volume
  • Total lung capacity
  • Respiratory rate
  • Vital capacity
  • Inspiratory reserve volume

(Mnemonic: TIMM increases in pregnancy)

Related Pearl: Lung volumes and capacities

Measurement

Description

Normal Value

Tidal volume (TV)

The amount of air that moves into the lungs with each inspiration (or the amount that moves out with each expiration) during quiet breathing

500–750 mL.

Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV)

The air inspired with a maximal inspiratory effort in excess of the TV

∼3 L

Expiratory reserve volume (ERV)

The volume expelled by an active expiratory effort after passive expiration

∼1.1 L

Residual volume (RV)

The air left in the lungs after a maximal expiratory effort

∼1.2 L

∼3.5 L

∼2.3 L

questions.text: A woman at 20 weeks of gestation has come for regular follow-up. Which cardiovascular changes listed below should you expect to find in this woman?
questions.solution:
The cardiovascular change that would be found in this normal patient is lateral displacement of the apical impulse. 

Cardiac functional changes become apparent in the first eight weeks of gestation. Lateral displacement of the apical impulse occurs due to progressive elevation of the diaphragm. This leads to a larger cardiac shadow on radiographs.

At apical or pulmonary area, systolic murmur may be heard due to decreased blood viscosity and torsion of great vessels. Mammary murmur is a continuous hissing sound heard over the tricuspid area in the left second and third intercostal spaces.

Other options:

All the other options are pathological changes.

Option A: Mid-diastolic and late diastolic murmurs can be seen in conditions like mitral stenosis. 

Option B: Pansystolic murmur can be seen in conditions like chronic mitral regurgitation and ventricular septal defect. 

Option C: Bradycardia in pregnancy can be seen in conditions like maternal complete heart block and cardiac pacemaker users.

Related Pearl: Cardiovascular changes in pregnancy

  • The resting pulse rate increases by 10 beats/min
  • The apex is moved laterally 
  • Cardiac output remains elevated throughout (maximum in the immediate postpartum period)
  • X-Ray shows a larger cardiac silhouette (due to benign pericardial effusion and shifted apex)
  • ECG: Slight left axis deviation

Heart sounds:

  • First heart sound: Loud with an exaggerated split
  • Second heart sound: Normal but loud
  • Third heart sound: Loud and easily heard

Murmurs:

  • A systolic murmur that was intensified during inspiration or expiration
  • A soft diastolic murmur (in 20%)
  • Continuous murmur arising from the breast vasculature (in 10%)

questions.text: A paramedic in the ambulance is examining a G2P1 lady, who is in labor. Her vitals are stable, her uterus is term-sized, and the fetus is in cephalic presentation. However, the cord was found to be prolapsed outside the vulva. Which of the following first aid measures should not be done by the ambulance staff?

choices.text: Put her in exaggerated Sim's position
Adjust stretcher for reverse Trendelenburg position
Place 2 fingers in the vagina and elevate the presenting part

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette suggests cord prolapse, and the patient should be put in a Trendelenburg position (not reverse Trendelenburg). This relieves cord compression by elevating the presenting part, till definitive management can be undertaken.

The definitive treatment for cord prolapse is delivery by cesarean section. Till then, the following first aid measures can be carried out:

  • IV fluids, oxygen by face mask, and continuous fetal monitoring
  • Stop oxytocin, if ongoing
  • Manual elevation of the fetal presenting part using two fingers or the whole hand through the vagina. (Option D)
  • Positioning of the patient in a steep Trendelenburg position, exaggerated Sim’s position (Option A), or knee-chest position
  • Vagos method (Option B): A Foley catheter is placed, and the bladder is filled with 500-750 mL of saline and then clamped. The patient’s enlarging bladder provides upward pressure on the fetus and alleviates the compression on the cord.
  • Funic reduction: Gentle replacement of the umbilical cord into the uterus. It is not preferred nowadays.
  • Tocolysis can be considered if there is a prolonged interval before delivery

Given below are the images of Trendelenburg's position, exaggerated Sim’s position, and knee-chest position, respectively:

questions.text:
A patient comes for a follow-up 2 years after her pregnancy. She had developed peripartum cardiomyopathy in her previous pregnancy and has been slowly recovering and now has an LVEF of 47%. She now wants to try for another child. What will be your advice to this patient?

LVEF - Left ventricular ejection fraction

choices.text: Advice her not to attempt any future pregnancies
Wait for LVEF to increase to >60% and then try for another pregnancy
Prescribe prenatal vitamins and assure her of a good prognosis
Advice her to take a beta blocker before trying for another pregnancy

questions.solution:
This patient with a past history of peri-partum cardiomyopathy(PPCM) now wants to try for another child. The right advice to give her would be to not try for any further pregnancies due to high cardiovascular morbidity and a risk of relapse of her heart failure. 

1/3rds of women who have another pregnancy after PPCM will have worsening symptoms again, and this patient who has still not recovered a normal EF even after more than 6 months should be strongly discouraged from becoming pregnant again due to the associated poor prognosis.

PPCM is defined as newly diagnosed systolic cardiomyopathy (LVEF < 45% or fractional shortening < 30%) without a reversible cause, presenting between the last month of gestation and 5 months postpartum(Harrison’s says 6 months) most commonly in the first month postpartum) in a woman without known CVD.

Risk factors include

  • Multiparity
  • Multiple gestation
  • Diabetes
  • Family history
  • Race/ethnicity (eg, African American)
  • Smoking
  • Cocaine use
  • Long-term (> 4 weeks) use of beta-adrenergic tocolytic therapy (eg, terbutaline)
  • Hypertension, and preeclampsia

Endomyocardial biopsy usually does not add useful information that warrants the risk of the procedure and shows tissue edema, myocardial hypertrophy, and varying degrees of fibrosis.

questions.text: A 21-year-old primigravida presented at 22 weeks of gestation with the results of the anomaly scan. The sonographic report showed a singleton fetus with normal amniotic fluid volume. There was a sudden termination of the spine above the level of the iliac wings and abnormal positioning of the lower extremities. Which among the following is likely to be found in this patient?

choices.text: Blood pressure of 160/100 mmHg with proteinuria

questions.solution:
The clinical case described with the mentioned ultrasound findings suggests caudal regression sequence/ sacral agenesis, which is associated with overt or pregestational diabetes with high HbA1C levels ≥ 6.5.

Caudal regression sequence is a rare anomaly, characterized by the absence of the sacral spine and sometimes portions of the lumbar spine as well. It is 25 times more prevalent in pregnancies complicated by diabetes. Poorly controlled diabetes is the underlying factor for this malformation risk.

Sonography shows an abnormally short spine lacking normal lumbosacral curvature, which terminates abruptly above the level of the iliac wings. Since the sacrum does not lie between the iliac wings, they may appear shield-like because they are abnormally close together. Abnormal positioning of the lower extremities and lack of nor­mal local soft tissue development may also be seen.

The image below shows a case of sacral agenesis.

Overt diabetes may be pre-existing or detected for the first time during the present pregnancy. The following criteria are used to diagnose it according to the American Diabetes Association:

  • Random plasma glucose level of >200 mg/dL plus classic signs and symptoms such as polydipsia, polyuria, and unexplained weight loss
  • Fasting glucose level of >126 mg/dL
  • First-trimester glycosylated hemoglobin (HbA1c) level of ≥6.5%

Other options:

Option B: Blood pressure of 160/100 mmHg with proteinuria points to preeclampsia, which can lead to intrauterine death, intrauterine growth restriction, asphyxia, or prematurity of the fetus.

Option C: Use of valproate in pregnancy leads to neural tube defects, cardiac anomalies, and developmental delay. 

Option D: Lithium leads to Ebstein's anomaly if taken during pregnancy. Ebstein's anomaly is characterized by apical displacement of the tricuspid valve, leading to severe tricuspid regurgitation and marked right atrial enlargement.

Related Pearl: Teratogenic drugs and the birth defects

Drugs Adverse effects
Penicillamine Cutis laxa syndrome
Lithium Ebstein anomaly
Isotretinoin Facial-ear anomalies, heart disease, CNS anomalies
Progesterone Masculinization of the female fetus
Quinine Abortion, thrombocytopenia, deafness
Topiramate Cleft lip
Valproate Spina bifida, limb defects, autism spectrum disorder, facial and cardiac anomalies, Coarctation of the aorta, Aortic stenosis, Pulmonary atresia, Ventricular Septal Defect. 
Vitamin D Supravalvular aortic stenosis
Warfarin Fetal bleeding, hypoplastic nasal structures
Statins Vertebral, anal, cardiac, tracheoesophageal fistula, renal, arterial, limb (VACTERAL) defects
Phenytoin Ventricular septal defect, Atrial Septal Defect, Coarctation of the aorta, Patent Ductus Arteriosus
ACE inhibitors and ARBs

Hypoplasia of organs, anuria, irreversible renal failure
Carbimazole and Methimazole  

Choanal atresia, aplasia cutis, tracheoesophageal fistula and fetal goiter
Alcohol Atrial Septal Defect, Ventricular Septal Defect

questions.text: What is the primary mechanism by which the development of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) takes place in the fetus of a diabetic mother?

choices.text: Inhibition of type II pneumocyte activation by cortisol
Inhibition of type II pneumocyte activation by insulin
Inhibition of type I pneumocyte activation by cortisol
Inhibition of type I pneumocyte activation by insulin

questions.solution:
The primary mechanism by which the development of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) takes place in the fetus of the diabetic mother is by inhibition of type II pneumocyte activation by insulin.

Due to maternal hyperglycemia in diabetes, there is hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the fetal islets of Langerhans leading to increased secretion of fetal insulin.

Excessive fetal insulin blocks the action of cortisol. Cortisol is responsible for activating type II pneumocytes to synthesize surfactants(phospholipids). Risk is reduced when diabetes is well-controlled and delivery is done after 38 weeks of gestation.

questions.text: A 33-year-old pregnant woman at 20 weeks of gestation has the following finding on USG. Identify the defect.
questions.solution:
The given ultrasound image shows scalloping of the frontal bones known as the lemon sign. It is seen in meningoencephalocele. 

Encephalocele is caused due to defects in the skull through which the meninges and/or neural tissue herniate. The squamous part of the occipital bone is the most frequently affected bone. In meningoencephalocele or occult spina bifida with Chiari malformations, the scalloping of the frontal bones is observed in the ultrasound as the lemon sign while anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa forms the banana sign. 

 The image shows a newborn with encephalocele. 

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign on USG as seen below.

The scalloping of the frontal bones is observed in the ultrasound as the lemon sign as seen below.

Other options:

Option A: Anencephaly results from incomplete closure of the neural tube. It is one of the earliest detectable congenital defects that can be detected as early as 10 to 11 weeks of gestation. Screening can also be done by serum estimation of maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP). The following are the radiological signs seen in anencephaly - 

 Frog eye sign - Absence of cranial calvaria, prominent orbits thereby resembling the face of a frog. 

Option C: Acrania is the absence of the cranium, with protrusion of a disorganized mass of brain tissue. This anomaly is more prevalent in first birth and about 70% of fetuses are females. 

The USG shows characteristic triangular facial appearance and shower cap sign.

Option D: Omphalocele is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen. The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac. These are due to the persistence of physiological herniation of the gut or as a part of the OEIS complex (omphalocele, exstrophy, imperforate anus, and spinal abnormality) and cloacal exstrophy. 

The image below shows an omphalocele.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)
