Related Pearl: Fetal Monitoring using Ultrasound

  • The first definitive USG finding to suggest pregnancy is the visualization of the gestational sac.
  • The first sign of intrauterine pregnancy is the presence of yolk sac within the gestational sac.
  • Best time to assess gestational age by USG is 9-12 weeks(by CRL)
  • CRL(mm)+42 = Days of pregnancy
  • CRL(cm)+6.5 = Gestational age in weeks.
  • The best indicator of fetal growth is the abdominal circumference. Abdominal circumference is the transverse measurement at the level of the stomach with the confluence of the umbilical vein and right portal vein.

questions.text: In a pregnant woman, on performing Leopold's 1st grip, you are able to palpate a freely mobile, hard and globular mass. Which of the following fetal parts is the denominator in this case?
questions.solution:
If a freely mobile, hard and globular mass is found on the 1st Leopold's grip, the fetus is in a longitudinal lie, in podalic/ breech presentation, and hence will have sacrum as the denominator.

The fetal denominator refers to the bony fixed point of reference on the presenting part with respect to different quadrants of the pelvis. The denominators for various presentations are as follows:

Presentation Denominator
Breech Sacrum
Vertex Occiput
Face Mentum (chin)
Brow Frontal eminence
Shoulder Acromion

 Note: The question refers to a breech pregnancy hence the part felt on the 1st Leopold's grip would be a smooth, hard globular mass indicative of head. The image provided is that of a fetus in a normal longitudinal lie, vertex presentation.

Fetal pole, lie, presenting part, engagement, and attitude of fetal head are assessed by Leopold's maneuvers:

Leopold grip Also known as Importance
First Fundal grip To know which fetal pole occupies the uterine fundus.
Second Lateral/ Umbilical grip To know the fetal back and extremities 
Third Pawlick grip

To know the presenting fetal part in respect to the true pelvis
Fourth Pelvic grip

To determine the degree of descent.

If the head has already descended into the pelvis, the anterior shoulder or the space created by neck may be differentiated readily from the head

 

Interpretation of various fetal parts felt in Leopold's grips:

  • Large, soft, nodular mass - indicates breech 
  • Hard, round, mobile mass - indicates head  
  • Uniform curved hard resistance- indicates back
  • Small, irregular, mobile parts- indicate fetal extremities 

Definitions of various terminologies used for the fetus in utero:

  • Lie: Relationship of the long axis of the fetus to the long axis of the maternal spine.
  • Presentation: Part of the fetus occupying the lower pole of the pelvis.
  • Presenting part: Part of the presentation which overlies the internal os.
  • Attitude: The relation of the different parts of the fetus to one another.
  • Position: Relation of the denominator to the different quadrants of the pelvis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida at 28 weeks gestation came with nausea, vomiting, and right upper quadrant pain for the past 2 days. She was diagnosed with gestational hypertension 2 weeks back.  She is now found to have HELLP syndrome. What is the characteristic pattern of liver necrosis in the syndrome?
questions.solution:
The characteristic pattern of liver necrosis in HELLP syndrome is periportal hemorrhagic necrosis.

HELLP syndrome constitutes hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelet count. The typical features are nausea, vomiting, and right upper quadrant pain due to the formation of subcapsular hematoma.

Laboratory findings are thrombocytopenia(<100,000/mm3), elevated aspartate transaminase (AST), and alanine transaminase (AST and ALT >70 IU/L). Elevated serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH >600 IU/L), and bilirubin (>1.2 mg/dL). Peripheral blood smear findings are Schizocytosis, spherocytosis, and reticulocytosis.

HELLP syndrome can also be associated with other complications such as eclampsia, placental abruption, stroke, coagulopathy, and pulmonary edema. 

Prompt delivery is indicated for ≥34 weeks of gestational age. Cesarean section is the common mode of delivery. Platelet transfusion is required if counts are less than 50,000/mm3. Magnesium sulfate is given as antiseizure prophylaxis, and anti-hypertensives are given for severe hypertension.

In the given image, area 1 in the red zone represents periportal necrosis.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents to the OPD with a swelling in her vagina and pain during sexual intercourse. On examination, a tense shiny swelling with well-defined margins is observed on the lateral vaginal wall. It does not have any rugosities. Cough impulse is absent. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the presence of a tender shiny swelling in the lateral vaginal wall with the absence of cough impulse points towards the diagnosis of a Gartner's cyst.

Gartner's cyst is a retention cyst in remnants of the Wolffian duct. It is typically an asymptomatic cyst that is found on the lateral wall of the vagina. Symptoms, if present include dyspareunia, vaginal pain, and difficulty inserting tampons. Examination findings include a tense shiny swelling with well-defined margins that is palpable or seen to bulge from beneath the vaginal wall.

Management involves excision or marsupialization of cyst in symptomatic cases

Other options

Option A - Epidermoid cysts (or epidermal inclusions) are skin-colored round-oval cysts commonly found on the vulva. It is caused by the traumatic implantation of epidermal cells into deep tissues or due to plugged pilosebaceous units.  Usually, they are located beneath the epidermis in the anterior half of the labia majora.

Option B - Cystocele is the prolapse of the urinary bladder into the vagina. It appears as a reducible swelling with ill-defined margins, rugosities, and a cough impulse. It is often associated with urinary symptoms.

Option C - Bartholin glands produce mucus for the lubrication of the vulva and vagina. Obstruction of this gland leads to Bartholin cyst. It is identified by its anatomic location, i.e. inferior part of labia majora or lower vestibular area. It is usually asymptomatic but becomes painful when infected.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a prerequisite for operative vaginal delivery?
questions.solution:
Membranes must be ruptured as a prerequisite for operative vaginal delivery.

Prerequisites for operative vaginal delivery are:

  • Engaged head
  • Vertex presentation
  • Known fetal head position
  • Adequate pelvis
  • Fetal weight estimated
  • Experienced operator
  • Ruptured membranes
  • Completely dilated cervix
  • Adequate anesthesia
  • Emptied maternal bladder
  • No fetal coagulopathy
  • No fetal demineralization disorder
  • Informed consent with a prior clear explanation
  • Willingness to abandon operative vaginal delivery

Operative vaginal delivery is any delivery process assisted by vaginal operations. Delivery with the help of forceps, ventouse, and destructive operations are included.

questions.text: False statement regarding scar dehiscence is

choices.text: Disruption of part of scar and not the entire length
Uterine cavity and peritoneal cavity become continuous
Bleeding is almost nil or minimal

questions.solution:
The uterine cavity and peritoneal cavity become continuous in case of scar rupture and not dehiscence.

Scar dehiscence is the asymptomatic separation of the uterine scar without the involvement of the peritoneal coat. It is characterized by:

  • Only a part of the scar is disrupted and not the entire length (Option A)
  • The fetal membranes are intact (Option B)
  • Almost nil or minimal bleeding (Option D)

Scar rupture is characterized by the complete separation of all the uterine layers including the serosa. It is characterized by:

  • The entire length of the scar is disrupted
  • Rupture of the membranes with varying amounts of bleeding from the margins or from its extension
  • The uterine cavity and peritoneal cavity become continuous

questions.text: A primigravida comes to you for her first antenatal visit. You discover on routine investigations that her blood group is B negative while her husband is B positive. You reassure her and explain to her the role of anti-D injections in the prevention of red cell alloimmunization. Which of the following is false about anti-D immunoprophylaxis?

choices.text: The half-life of anti-D immune globulin is 60 days
First dose is given at 28 weeks of gestation to D-negative, unsensitized Rh-negative women
Second dose is given within 72 hours of delivery and only if the baby is Rh-positive with direct Coombs’ test negative
300 μg of anti-D immune globulin can neutralize 15 mL of fetal RBCs

questions.solution:
The half-life of anti-D immune globulin is not 60 days. Hence, option A is false regarding anti-D immunoprophylaxis.

The half-life of anti-D immune globulin ranges from 16 to 24 days, depending on the preparation. (Option A) This is the reason why it is given in both the third trimester and following delivery. 

All D-negative, unsensitized women should receive anti-D Ig at approximately 28 weeks of gestation (Option B). The second dose is given within 72 hours of the delivery and the newborn is D-positive (Option C).

300 μg or 1500 IU is the standard intramuscular dose of anti-D Ig. It will protect the average-sized mother from fetal hemorrhage of up to 30 mL of whole fetal blood or 15 mL of fetal red cells (Option D). Kleihauer-Betke test is used to estimate the approximate volume of fetal blood that enters the maternal circulation.

The protocol for Rh isoimmunization is as follows:

questions.text: A primigravida with suspected intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) is referred for the ultrasound of the abdomen. The radiologist is assessing the abdominal circumference of the fetus in a transverse plane that includes all of the following, except
questions.solution:
The abdominal circumference is measured in a transverse plane, including the stomach, and J-shaped confluence of the umbilical vein with the portal sinus. The kidneys and cord insertion are not included in this plane as they are lower in the abdomen.

Abdominal circumference is the biometric parameter most affected by fetal growth. Fetal growth restriction is suspected when it is below the 10th percentile. 

The image below shows the plane of abdominal circumference.

Trimester Parameter
First Crown-rump length (CRL)
Second Biparietal diameter (BPD)
Third Femur length (FL)

Related Pearl: Fetal Monitoring using Ultrasound

  • The first definitive USG finding to suggest pregnancy is the visualization of the gestational sac.
  • The first sign of intrauterine pregnancy is the presence of yolk sac within the gestational sac.
  • Best time to assess gestational age by USG is 9-12 weeks(by CRL)
  • CRL(mm)+42 = Days of pregnancy
  • CRL(cm)+6.5 = Gestational age in weeks.
  • The best indicator of fetal growth is the abdominal circumference. Abdominal circumference is the transverse measurement at the level of the stomach with the confluence of the umbilical vein and right portal vein.

questions.text: Which of the following structures are not a content of broad ligament of the uterus?
questions.solution:
Fimbriae of the fallopian tube are not a content of broad ligament. The fallopian tube proper is a content of the broad ligament.

The broad ligament of the uterus is a double-layer fold of the peritoneum that attaches the lateral portions of the uterus to the lateral pelvic wall on either side. It consists of anterior and posterior leaves that separate to enclose viscera and blood vessels. The broad ligament is divided into:

  • Mesometrium - this is the largest portion related to the uterus
  • Mesosalpinx - represents the mesentery of the fallopian tubes
  • Mesovarium - connects the anterior part of the ovaries to the broad ligament.

The anatomical boundaries of the broad ligament are as follows:

  • Superiorly - round ligaments;
  • Posteriorly - infundibulopelvic ligaments
  • Inferiorly - cardinal and uterosacral ligaments. 

The broad ligament and the round ligament serve as secondary supports of the uterus.

Clinical significance:

  • Formation of the vesicouterine pouch between the bladder and the anterior part of the uterus.
  • Formation of the rectouterine pouch between the rectum and the posterior part of the uterus. This is also known as the pouch of Douglas or posterior pelvic cul-de-sac. It forms the most dependent part when a woman is sitting or standing. Thus, accumulation of fluid occurs in various pathologies which can be aspirated and studied by performing a culdocentesis. 
  • A potential site for endometriosis
  • Malignant leiomyosarcomas and lipoleiomyomas can arise from the broad ligament.
Epoophoron and paroophoron are vestigial structures of the Wolffian body present in the broad ligament

The infundibulopelvic ligament is that portion of the broad ligament that extends from the infundibulum of the fallopian tube to the lateral pelvic wall. It encloses the ovarian vessels, lymphatics, and nerves of the ovary. Hence, ovarian vessels are a content of the broad ligament.

Related Pearl: Contents of the Broad ligament

  • One tube - Fallopian tube
  • Two ligaments:
    • Round ligament of uterus
    • Ovarian ligament
  • Two arteries:
    • Uterine artery
    • Ovarian artery
  • Two nerve plexus:
    • Uterovaginal plexus
    • Ovarian plexus
  • Three embryological remnants:
    • Epoophoron (Wolffian body)
    • Paroophoron (Wolffian body)
    • Gartner’s duct (Wolffian duct)
  • Other structures:
    • Lymph vessels and lymph nodes
    • Fibrous connective tissue

questions.text: The following statement is correct regarding Mullerian agenesis, except:

choices.text: The condition should be evaluated for congenital renal or skeletal anomalies.
Pregnancy can be achieved using oocyte retrieval.
Associated with skeletal malformations such as spina bifida, sacralization

questions.solution:
All are correct statements regarding Mullerian agenesis except option D. Typically normal ovaries are present in this condition hence this statement is wrong.

Congenital absence of both the uterus and vagina is termed Mullerian agenesis or Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome.
In classic Mullerian agenesis, patients have a shallow vaginal pouch(1 to 2 inches deep). The uterus, cervix, and upper part of the vagina are absent. Typically, normal ovaries persist, as they originate from the genital ridge. Individual presents with primary amenorrhea, have a normal female appearance, secondary sexual characteristics, and 46 XX karyotype. Most patients with Mullerian agenesis have only small rudimentary mullerian bulbs without endometrial activity. 

With mullerian agenesis, traditional conception is not possible, but pregnancy may be achieved using oocyte retrieval, fertilization, and gestational surrogacy.

Individuals with Mullerian agenesis or hypoplasia have associated congenital renal or skeletal anomalies. Common renal anomalies include ectopic- horseshoe or pelvic kidney and collecting system anomalies. Skeletal malformations include spina bifida, sacralization (partial fusion of L5 to the sacrum), sacral bone lumbarization (nonfusion of the first and second sacral segments), and cervical vertebral anomalies.

Related Pearl: Disorders of Sexual Development

Disorder

Complete androgen insensitivity

Mullerian agenesis

Turner syndrome

Complete XY dysgenesis (Swyer syndrome)

Cause

X-linked mutation of androgen receptor

Hypoplastic or absent Mullerian ductal system

Also called Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome

Complete or partial absence of one X chromosome

SRY gene mutation on the Y chromosome

Reproductive organs

Absent uterus and upper vagina, cryptorchid testis

Absent or rudimentary uterus and upper vagina, normal ovaries

Normal uterus and vagina, streak gonads

Normal uterus and vagina, streak gonads

Breast

Yes

Yes

Variable

No

Axillary/Pubic hair

Minimal to absent

Normal

Normal

Minimal to absent

Karyotype

46 XY

46 XX

45 XO or 

45 X mosaicism

46 XY

 

Note: 

Turner's syndrome have different chromosomal anomalies:

  • 45 XO which is seen in 40-50% patients 
  • 45 X mosaicism (eg, 45,X/46,XX or 45,X/47,XXX, or 45,X mosaics with the X chromosome anomalies)

questions.text: A pregnant woman in labor started bleeding profusely immediately after artificial rupture of membranes and emergency LSCS was performed. The placenta of the patient is given below. Identify the type of placenta.
questions.solution:
The type of placenta shown in the image is the velamentous placenta. The image shows velamentous cord insertion, where the umbilical cord is attached to the fetal membranes. The cord vessels traverse between the membranes for some distance before reaching the placenta.

The scenario described is suggestive of vasa previa, in which part of the membrane with the vessels lies in front of the presenting part and above the internal os. The rupture of the membranes involving the overlying vessels leads to vaginal bleeding and fetal exsanguination.

Battledore placenta: The cord is attached to the margin of the placenta.

Succenturiate placenta: One or small lobes of placenta lies separate from the main part and is connected to the main part by a leash of blood vessels passing through the membrane.

Circumvallate placenta - The fetal surface of the placenta is covered by a white ring at the periphery made up of a double fold of amnion and chorion.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions does not show the finding seen in the image below?
questions.solution:
The cardiotocograph shows a sinusoidal fetal heart rate pattern and is not seen in fetal head compression which shows early deceleration. Fetal head compression typically shows early deceleration.

A sinusoidal pattern is seen in the following conditions:

  • Fetal intracranial hemorrhage
  • Severe fetal asphyxia
  • Severe fetal anemia - Due to anti-D alloimmunization, feto-maternal hemorrhage, bleeding from vasa previa, parvovirus infection, and twin-twin transfusion syndrome.
  • Administration of opioid analgesics - pethidine, morphine, alphaprodine, and butorphanol

The pattern is characterized by a stable baseline heart rate between 120-160 with regular sinusoidal oscillations. The amplitude of the oscillations is usually between 5-15 beats per minute and accelerations are absent.

Other cardiotocography patterns:

Early deceleration:

Uniform, repetitive periodic slowing of FHR and in most cases the onset of the uterine contraction and recovery of deceleration coincide with the beginning, peak, and ending of uterine contraction respectively. It is due to head compression (vagal nerve activation)

 Late deceleration:

Uniform, repetitive periodic slowing of FHR. It begins after the onset of the uterine contraction. Usually, the onset, nadir, and recovery of the deceleration occur after the start, peak, and end of the uterine contraction respectively. Nadir occurs 20 seconds after the peak of the contraction and FHR returns to normal after the contraction is over. It suggests uteroplacental insufficiency and fetal hypoxia.

Variable deceleration:

It is the intermittent periodic slowing (variable) of FHR with rapid onset and recovery. Decelerations are variable in all respect of size, shape, depth, duration, and timing to the uterine contractions. It is thought to indicate cord compression and may disappear with the change in position of the patient. Accelerations often precede and follow the deceleration.

questions.text: A primigravida presented with labor pains at 38 weeks of gestation. The baby was in breech presentation and a vaginal breech delivery was planned. Identify the following maneuver performed during the delivery.
questions.solution:
The given maneuver is the modified Prague maneuver done for a chin-to-pubis delivery of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

Note: If the back is oriented anteriorly, extraction may be accomplished using the Mauriceau maneuver.

Other options:

Wood's corkscrew maneuver is used to manage shoulder dystocia. It involves the pro­gressive rotation of the posterior shoulder 180 degrees in a cork­screw fashion to release the impacted anterior shoulder. 

In the Zavanelli maneuver, the fetal head is rotated to the direct occiput anterior position and pushed back into the uterus so that the fetus can be delivered by cesarean section. The cardinal movements of labor are reversed. It is done as a third line of managing shoulder dystocia after failing to deliver the baby vaginally.

Lovset maneuver is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Related Pearl: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

 

Lovset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 

 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

  • Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.
  • Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.
  • Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.
  • Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.
  • Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.

 

Mnemonic:

  • Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)
  • Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

questions.text:
A 34-year-old woman at 30 weeks of gestation presents with complaints of bleeding PV and severe abdominal pain. She has drenched her clothes and has experienced decreased fetal movements. On examination, her cervix was 3 cm dilated and 50% effaced. Her BP was 150/100mmHg, PR - 100 beats/min and her urine protein was +2. She had a tense and tender uterus with regular contractions and a FHR of 90 beats/min. What is the ideal management?

FHR - Fetal heart rate
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of painful antepartum haemorrhage associated with pre-eclampsia (hypertension + proteinuria) and reduced fetal heart rate is suggestive of Grade 2 abruptio placentae. In this case, as the fetus has a reduced heart rate and the patient has a cervix which is only dilated 3cm, the best approach would be to administer antihypertensives and deliver the fetus via cesarean section.

Abruptio placenta is the partial/total placental separation from its implantation site before delivery. The bleeding may be:

  • Revealed - blood dissects downwards between membranes and uterine wall to escape through the cervix
  • Concealed - blood accumulates between the detached placenta and uterus, and the uterus is larger than expected for the period of gestation
  • Mixed - features of both co-existing

Hypertension in pregnancy is the most important risk factor for abruptio placenta. Spasm of the decidual spiral artery leads to endothelial damage and extravasation of blood in the placental bed, leading to fetal distress.  Patients often present with sudden onset abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, uterine tenderness, and frequent contractions. Based on the degree of  placental separation, patients are clinically graded as follows:

  • Grade 0 – Asymptomatic, abruption is diagnosed only after delivery by the presence of retroplacental clots.
  • Grade 1 – Vaginal bleeding, mild uterine tetani. No maternal and fetal complications.
  • Grade 2 – With fetal distress or death
  • Grade 3 – With maternal complications like shock, renal failure, coagulopathy, or death.

The management of abruption is based on whether the patient is in labor and the fetal status, with the goal being to expedite delivery and prevent complications such as shock and coagulopathy. Immediate management begins with the administration of IV crystalloids and arrangement of blood for the patient, along with BP control.

  • If the patient is in labour and the cervix is favourable, in case the fetal heart rate is reassuring, or in case the fetus has died - amniotomy and vaginal delivery. (Option B)
  • If the patient is not in labour or fetal heart tracing indicates fetal distress - an emergency caesarean section is indicated. 

Other Options:

Options C and D: Abruption is considered an obstetric emergency and hence tocolytics or expectant management have no place in the management of this patient.

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida delivered a baby at term with a birth weight of 2.5 kg via normal vaginal delivery. The placenta delivered appears as shown in the image below. Which of the following complications is less likely to be associated with this placental variant?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a bilobed placenta, also known as placenta bilobate or bipartite placenta or placenta duplex. Fetal growth restriction is not a complication likely to be associated with this placental variant.

A bilobed placenta is described as the presence of two, almost equally sized placental lobes separated by a membrane, without significant vasculature present in between them. The umbilical cord may be inserted between the two placental lobes into the chorionic bridge, or into the intervening membranes, or in a velamentous fashion. The presence of more than two lobes is termed as multilobate placenta and is rare.

The complications associated with this placental variant:

  • First-trimester bleeding
  • Polyhydramnios
  • Abruption
  • Retained placenta

The types of placental variants:

  • Placenta succenturiata: One or more unequally sized smaller placental lobes at distant sites from the bulk of the placenta. Vessels are present in the intervening membranes that connect the two lobes. It is associated with complications like vasa previa, postpartum uterine atony, postpartum hemorrhage, and endometritis. An image of this variant is given below where L1,2,3 depicts smaller lobes, UC is the umbilical cord, and M is the intervening membrane. 
  • Placenta membranacea: Unduly large and thin placenta that develops from both the chorionic frondosum and the chorion leave. It is associated with an increased risk of placenta previa or accreta and retained placenta and its complications.
  • Ring-shaped placenta: This is a variant of placenta membranacea where a partial or complete ring of the placenta is present. This variant is associated with an increased risk of antepartum and postpartum bleeding and fetal-growth restric­tion.
  • Placenta fenestrata: In this, the central portion of a placental disc is missing.
  • Battledore placenta: In this, the umbilical cord is inserted at or near the placental margin rather than at the center. When inserted 2 cm away it is known as velamentous cord insertion. A specimen of battledore placenta is given below:
  • Extrachorial placentation: the chorionic plate is smaller than the basal plate. There are two types of extrachorial placentation:
    • Circummarginate placenta - In this type, the space between the fetal membranes and the basal plate is filled up by fibrin and old hemorrhage with a smooth margin.
    • Circumvallate placenta - In this type, the peripheral chorion is thickened into a ridge composed of a double fold of chorion and amnion. Complications associated with circumvallate placenta are preterm delivery, abortions, growth retardation, antepartum hemorrhage, retained placenta, and hydrorrhea gravidarum. A specimen of circumvallate placenta is shown below:

questions.text: A primigravida female at 31 weeks of gestation presents with complaints of excessive fatigue. On examination, she had severe pallor and her hemoglobin was 4.9 g/dL. Which among the following is the best treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
The best treatment option for this patient with severe anemia at 31 weeks of gestation is packed cell transfusion.

The treatment of choice for anemia with Hb <5 g/dL at <34 weeks of gestation with or without signs of cardiac failure or hypoxia is packed cell transfusion.

Following are the indications for initiating blood transfusion during pregnancy:

Antepartum period

  1. Pregnancy <34 weeks:
    1. Hb <5 g/dL with or without signs of cardiac failure or hypoxia
    2. Hb 5-7 g/dL – in presence of impending heart failure
  2. Pregnancy >34 weeks:
    1. Hb <7 g/dL even without signs of cardiac failure or hypoxia
    2. Severe anemia with decompensation
  3. Anemia not due to hematinic deficiency
  4. Acute hemorrhage:
    1. Always indicated if Hb <6 g/dL
    2. If the patient becomes hemodynamically unstable due to ongoing hemorrhage

Intrapartum period

  • Hb <7 g/dL 
  • The decision of blood transfusion depends on medical history or symptoms

Postpartum period

  • Hb <7 g/dL 
  • Anemia with signs of shock/acute hemorrhage with signs of hemodynamic instability

Only partial exchange and packed cell transfusion is recommended during pregnancy. A quantity of 80 mL-100 mL is to be administered at a time. Transfusion should not be repeated within 24 hours to allow time for circulatory readjustment.

The following precautions are taken prior to blood transfusions:

  • There is an increased risk of cardiac failure with pulmonary edema, so utmost precautions are to be taken to minimize the overloading of the heart.
  • Administration of antihistaminics and diuretics intramuscularly at least 2 hours prior to transfusion to minimize transfusion reaction and diuretics help to produce negative fluid balance.
  • Adjustment of the drip rate to 10 drops/minute
  • Observation of the pulse, respiration, and basal lung crepitations

The complications of blood transfusions include premature labor, increased chances of worsening cardiac failure, and transfusion reactions.

Related Pearl: Morphological Classification of Anemias

 

Microcytic Hypochromic

(MCV <80 fl)

Normocytic Normochromic    

(MCV 80 - 100 fl)

Macrocytic Normochromic

(MCV >100 fl)

Iron deficiency anemia

Sideroblastic anemia

Thalassemia

Lead toxicity

Acute blood loss

Anemia of chronic disease

Anemia of renal disease

Hemolysis*

Bone marrow suppression

  • Aplastic anemia
  • Pure red cell aplasia

 

  

Megaloblastic:

Vitamin B12 deficiency

Folate deficiency

Thiamine deficiency

Drugs - Methotrexate, Zidovudine, hydroxyurea

Orotic aciduria

 

Non-megaloblastic:

Alcohol use

Liver disease

Hypothyroidism

Hemolysis*

 

*Hemolysis can be associated with macrocytosis because of compensatory reticulocytosis. However, MCV can be normal depending on the degree of hemolysis.

Note: In Orotic Aciduria, peripheral blood smear shows Hypochromic megaloblastic anemia.

questions.text: A 24-year-old G2P1L1 woman at 32 weeks of gestation presents with pruritus on the palms and soles for 2 weeks. She also had yellowish discoloration of the sclera. Her total bilirubin level was 3.8 mg/dL. Alkaline phosphatase levels were elevated, and serum transaminase levels were normal. She also reports that she had similar complaints during the previous pregnancy. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy.

Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy is a reversible cholestatic disease occurring in the 2nd or 3rd trimester. It is characterized by pruritus (worse on palms and soles and at the night) and icterus. It is also known as recurrent jaundice of pregnancy, cholestatic hepatosis, and icterus gravidarum.

Hyperbilirubinemia results from the retention of conjugated pigment, but total plasma concentrations rarely exceed 4 to 5 mg/dL. Serum transaminase levels are normal to moderately elevated, but seldom exceed 250 U/L. Total and fasting serum bile acid concentrations are elevated. Alkaline phosphatase levels are usually elevated. Liver biopsy shows mild cholestasis with bile plugs in the hepatocytes and canaliculi of the centrilobular region.

Management comprises antihistamines, topical emollients, cholestyramine, and ursodeoxycholic acid.

Other options:

Option B: Acute fatty liver of pregnancy manifests mostly in the last trimester of pregnancy with nausea, vomiting, anorexia, epigastric pain, and progressive jaundice. There may be hypertension, protein­uria, and edema. There is moderate to severe liver dysfunction with hypofi­brinogenemia, hypoalbuminemia, hypocholesterolemia, and prolonged clotting times. Serum bilirubin level is usually <10 mg/dL, and serum transaminases are ele­vated but <1000 U/L.

Option C: Acute viral hepatitis is usually asymptomatic. When symptomatic, it presents with nausea, vomiting, and malaise, followed by jaundice. Low-grade fever may be present. Serum bilirubin rises, and transaminase levels vary.

Option D: Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease is commonly associated with obesity, type 2 diabetes, and hyperlipidemia­ syndrome. It is usually asymptomatic with elevated transaminases.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents with high levels of serum β-hCG (>1 lakh mIU/mL) and the ultrasound of the abdomen shows the following finding. Which of the following phenomena is most frequently responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a pregnant woman with abnormally elevated HCG levels and snowstorm appearance in the ultrasound points towards a diagnosis of molar pregnancy (complete hydatidiform mole). The cytogenetic abnormality most commonly associated with complete mole is androgenesis. 

Hydatidiform moles may be either partial or complete:

  • Complete moles occur due to the fertilization of an egg that has lost its female chromosomes. In about 90% of the cases, the chromosomes are derived entirely from the father (androgenesis) (Option A). The genetic material of one sperm is duplicated, resulting in a diploid 46 XX karyotype. In the remaining 10% of the cases, the empty egg is fertilized by two sperms (dispermy), resulting in a diploid karyotype, either 46 XX or 46 XY. (Option B)
  • Partial moles occur due to the fertilization of an egg with two sperms. The karyotype is usually triploid (69 XXY) or occasionally tetraploid (92 XXXY) (Option A and D). It is associated with an increased risk of persistent molar disease but is not associated with choriocarcinoma.

Hydatidiform mole is an abnormal condition of the placenta primarily affecting the chorion. The patient presents with bleeding per vaginum or an acute discharge of vesicular mass per vaginum. On examination, the uterine size is more than the corresponding period of amenorrhea.

They may have thyrotoxic features, attributable to chorionic thyrotropin and breathlessness due to the pulmonary embolism of trophoblastic cells. History of quickening is absent. Vaginal bleeding is the commonest presentation.

It shows a characteristic snowstorm appearance on USG due to an echogenic uterine mass that has numerous anechoic cystic spaces.

The definitive management after diagnosis is suction and evacuation, after making the cervix favorable. 

Related Pearl: Complete vs. Partial Mole

Hydatidiform mole is a benign abnormal condition of the placenta characterized by partial degenerative or proliferative changes of the chorionic villi. Though benign, it has malignant potential. It is commonly seen in pregnancies of extreme reproductive age groups - teenage and women above 35 years of age. A previous history of molar pregnancy is also a strong risk factor for recurrence of this condition.

Molar pregnancy is of 2 types - complete mole and partial mole.

Feature Partial mole Complete mole
Karyotype 69 XYY or 69 XXY 46 XX or 46 XY
Diagnosis Missed abortion Molar gestation
Uterus size Small for date Large for date
Theca-lutein cysts Rare 25–30% of cases
Initial hCG levels <1 lakh mIU/ml >1 lakh mIU/ml
Medical complications Rare Uncommon
Rate of subsequent GTN 1–5% 15–20%
Embryo-fetus  Often present Absent
Amnion, fetal erythrocytes Often present Absent
Villous edema  Focal Widespread
Trophoblastic proliferation Focal, slight to moderate Slight to severe
Trophoblast atypia Mild Marked
p57KIP2 immunostaining Positive Negative

questions.text:
A primigravida was rushed to the emergency with generalized tonic-clonic seizures at 38 weeks of gestation. Her family reported her having complained of a headache and abdominal pain before the seizures. Her medical records showed that she was diagnosed with gestational hypertension at 22 weeks of gestation. Which of the following is false regarding further management of this patient?

DTR: Deep tendon reflexes
MgSO4: Magnesium sulfate

choices.text: Loading dose of MgSO4 should be reduced if urine output <30 mL/hr
Plasma magnesium levels need to be maintained at 4-7 mEq/L
Maintenance doses of MgSO4 are given only if DTRs are present
Calcium gluconate should be readily available while giving MgSO4

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes a case of eclampsia where the loading dose of 4 g IV MgSO4 is given irrespective of renal function status.

Although magnesium is cleared almost exclusively by renal excretion, the loading dose of magnesium sulfate can be safely administered regardless of renal function. Only the maintenance dose needs to be altered according to the renal function. This is because the loading dose is responsible for reaching therapeutic levels but the maintenance doses are responsible for maintaining steady states.

Magnesium sulfate is used for the management of eclampsia and as prophylaxis in severe pre-eclampsia. The therapeutic level of magnesium in eclampsia is 4-7 mEq/L. (Option B)

The two regimens commonly used are Pritchard and Sibai regimens.

Regimen Loading Dose Maintenance Dose
Intramuscular (Pritchard)  4 g (20% solution) IV over 3-5 minutes followed by 10 g (5O%), deep IM (5 g in each buttock)  5 g (5O%) IM 4 hourly in the alternate buttocks
Intravenous (Zuspan or Sibai)  4 g IV slow over 15-20 minute  1-2 g/h IV infusion

Patients must be monitored for magnesium toxicity:

  • Loss of deep tendon reflexes 
  • Decreased respiratory rate (<12 per min)
  • Urine output (<30 ml/h)
  • Chest pain, heart block

Repeated or maintenance dose IM injections are continued only if:

  • Patellar reflex (deep tendon reflex) is present (Option C)
  • Respirations are not depressed
  • Urine output in the previous 4 hours exceeded 100 mL

Management of magnesium toxicity:

  • Stop magnesium therapy
  • Estimation of serum magnesium and creatinine levels
  • Injection of calcium gluconate 10ml (10% solution) IV (Option D)

questions.text: A 33-year-old lady comes with a history of  7 weeks of amenorrhea, severe left-sided pelvic pain, and spotting PV. She gives a history of an IUCD inserted 3 years back, after her first pregnancy. A urine pregnancy test is weakly positive.  The findings of ultrasound and Doppler studies are shown below. What is true about the patient's condition?

choices.text: Salphingitis isthmica nodosa is associated with a higher incidence of the condition
Passage of a decidual cast rules out the given condition
The only treatment for it is surgical management
Doubling of beta-HCG values in 48 hours is highly suggestive of the condition

questions.solution:
Salpingitis isthmica nodosa is associated with a higher incidence of ectopic pregnancy.

This is a case of ectopic pregnancy, with the ultrasound color Doppler showing the ring-of-fire appearance in tubal ectopic pregnancy.   

Salpingitis isthmica nodosa is an inflammatory condition of the fallopian tube, characterized by nodular thickening of its isthmic portion. Histologically, the proliferation of smooth muscle and diverticula of tubal epithelium contribute to this thickening. This condition typically develops bilaterally. Since the tubal anatomy is altered, there is an increase in the risk of ectopic pregnancy.

The passage of a decidual cast is suggestive of ectopic pregnancy (Option B). The decidual cast has a smooth glistening inner surface and a shaggy maternal surface. The chorionic villi are absent.

Beta-HCG doubles every 2 days in a normal pregnancy (Option D). If the level does not rise or rises by less than 66% from the previous reading, it is suggestive of ectopic pregnancy. Beta-HCG in the urine and serum, empty uterus, adnexal mass, and free fluid in the peritoneal cavity is pathognomonic of an ectopic pregnancy. The ring of fire can be seen with color doppler imaging placental blood flow within the periphery of an ectopic pregnancy. 

Ectopic pregnancy can be managed with the following interventions: (Option C)

  • Expectant management: Ectopic pregnancies measuring <3 cm and with declining beta-hCG levels initially <1500 mIU/mL may resolve without inter­vention and can be managed expectantly. 
  • Medical management with single or multiple-dose methotrexate. Methotrexate(MTX) can be given as a single IM or as a multiple-dose regimen on days 1, 3, 5, and 7.
  • Surgical management for indicated cases is done with salpingectomy or salpingostomy.

Related Pearl: Beta hCG in pregnancy

The pattern of beta hCG :

First detectable in plasma 7 to 9 days post-LH surge
          ⇓
Doubles every 2 days
          ⇓
Peaks at 8 to 10 weeks of gestation(~100 IU/mL)
          ⇓
Begins to decline at 10 to 12 weeks
          ⇓
Plateau at 16 weeks till term
 
  • Higher maternal plasma hCG levels- Multifetal pregnancy, erythroblastosis fetalis, gestational trophoblastic disease, Down syndrome.
  • Lower hCG plasma levels -early pregnancy wastage and ectopic pregnancy.

questions.text: In the pelvic inlet, which is the shortest anteroposterior diameter?
questions.solution:
In the pelvic inlet, the obstetric conjugate is the shortest anteroposterior diameter.

Anteroposterior Diameter of pelvic inlet:

True conjugate: Also called anatomical conjugate, is the distance between the midpoint of the sacral promontory to the inner margin of the upper border of the symphysis pubis and measures 11 cm.

Obstetric conjugate: It is the distance between the midpoint of the sacral promontory to the prominent bony projection in the midline on the inner surface of the symphysis pubis. It is the shortest anteroposterior diameter in the anteroposterior plane of the inlet and measures 10 cm.

Diagonal conjugate: It is the distance between the lower border of the symphysis pubis to the midpoint on the sacral promontory. It measures 12 cm. Obstetric conjugate is derived by subtracting 1.5–2 cm from the diagonal conjugate depending upon the height, thickness and inclination of the symphysis pubis.

Pelvic inlet contraction is considered when the obstetric conjugate is <10 cm or the greatest transverse diameter is <12 cm or the diagonal conjugate is <11 cm.

The bispinous diameter measures 10.5 cm which is a transverse diameter of midpelvis plane. It measures between the two ischial spines.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with acute bleeding following delivery in the ambulance. On examination, a perineal tear was observed involving the anal sphincter and anal mucosa. The bleeding has been controlled. When is the ideal time to perform sphincter reconstructive surgery?
questions.solution:
As the patient was delivered in the ambulance on the way to the hospital, she has presented immediately (within 24 hours) with a complete perineal tear. Sphincter reconstructive surgery must be performed immediately.

A tear of the perineal body involving the sphincter ani externus with or without the involvement of anorectal mucosa is termed a complete perineal tear. Complete perineal tears (3rd or 4th-degree tears) that were not repaired in the first 24 hours should be operated on between 3-6 months after delivery.

In 3 months, local infection would subside with improvement in the general condition of the patient and baby can also be kept at home. Beyond 6 months, due to excessive fibrosis at the margin, it becomes inconvenient for the patient.

Related Pearl: Degrees of perineal laceration

Degree
Description
First-degree
Injury to the skin and subcutaneous tissue of the perineum and vaginal epithelium only. The perineal muscles remain intact.
Second-degree
Extends into the fascia and musculature of the perineal body. The anal sphincter muscles remain intact.
Third-degree 
3a
<50% of EAS thickness is torn
3b
>50% of EAS thickness is torn
3c
Both EAS and IAS are torn
Fourth-degree
Involves the perineal structures, EAS, IAS and rectal mucosa.
